content: using long tail cast on and join in the round this creates a little hole you ll have to sew closed in the end knitting round 1 knit around 6 round 2 kfb around 12 round 3 k1 kfb x6 18 round 4 k2 kfb x6 24 round 5 k3 kfb x6 30 round 6 k4 kfb x6 36 round 7 k5 kfb x6 42 round 8 k6 kfb x6 48 this is what it should look like round 9 k7 kfb x6 54 after round 9 round 10-30 knit around pattern by wildflower fibercrafts bind off bind off making sure not to bind off too tightly go up a needle size if necessary a tutorial for a basic bind off https //youtu be/vswjiuiqzlm si=bmedym-dbyvcqzcz important leave a long tail of both strands of yarn this will be used to sew the pouch into the clasp in the next step for a neater and more even result make sure to wash and block your pouch now this shouldn t be done after the clasp has been added since it could lead to rust your pouch should look something like this assembly this will ensure the fabric is divided evenly on both sides before sewing mark the sides of your pouch when laying flat with pins or stitch markers make sure you sew the pouch into the frame so that the markers are below the joints of the clasp pattern by wildflower fibercrafts to sew thread both strands of the yarn tails through a sewing needle hold your fabric in between the front and back panel of the clasp so that it fully covers the edge of the pouch then sew it in through the holes of the clasp once your pouch is fully assembled weave in and cut all ends done enjoy your new coin pouch <3 for a more detailed explanation and helpful tips please visit my blog where i give an in-depth explanation on every step along with a few tips and tricks on how to ensure your pouch comes out just right every time https //www awildflowerslife blog
